Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Expectation2: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation2: The build is stalled because no one can proceed until their core module is complete
Story: I stare at my laptop, the code for the core module blinking accusingly at me. The project manager’s messages pile up, each one more urgent than the last. I know the whole team is waiting for me—nothing can move forward until I finish this piece. My mind races with algorithms and deadlines, but then my phone buzzes. It’s a message from Mom: “Can we talk for a bit?” I remember how I promised myself to check in more, to be there for them, especially after Dad’s health scare last month. I know they rely on me, not just for updates, but for comfort, for reassurance that everything will be okay. I feel the weight of their expectations pressing against the demands of my job. My hands hover over the keyboard, torn between the code that everyone needs and the call that my parents are waiting for. My chest tightens as I try to decide which role I can let down less.
